awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2020 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Dennis Tseng is " Enumerative geometry and its connections to combinatorics and equivariant cohomology." The host institution for the fellowship Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Davesh Maulik.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Algebraic geometry is the study of the geometries of shapes coming from polynomial constraints. Because polynomial constraints are very special, algebraic geometry is a specialized tool, but it is potentially powerful when it can be applied. Therefore, we want to identify as many connections between algebraic geometry and other fields as possible. Even very theoretical fields have the potential to be applied to benefit society in the long run, and we want to ensure techniques that might only be currently understood by specialists to be eventually useful to all. During this postdoctoral research fellowship, we specific pursue connections two specific fields, which we will describe below.

Graphs are defined by a collection of points and edges between them. Graphs face the opposite problem as algebraic geometry above. Graphs are a very general object, with little structure, so they already are applied in many disciplines to solve problems. However, this generality comes at a cost, namely the lack of structure reduces the its effectiveness in dealing with any specific problem.

The main project pursued during the postdoctoral fellowship deals with the connection between certain graph invariants (more generally matroid invariants) and algebraic geometry. The general idea that has been pursued in the literature is to somehow encode the data of a graph in an algebraic variety. Then, we have the best of both worlds, since we can apply the specialized tools of algebraic geometry to a graph, which is a very general object.

Our preprint, "Tautological bundles of matroids", joint with A. Berget, C. Eur, and H. Spink, unifies many recent papers in the literature that fit the theme above, bringing clarity to the field.

The second direction pursued in the postdoctoral fellowship is the application of algebraic geometric techniques to equivariant cohomology. Cohomology is a tool in topology that can be used to understand the intersection of certain shapes. Equivariant cohomology allows one to exploit additional structure when there is symmetry. Intersection theory is an important subfield of algebraic geometry that also deals with understanding the intersection of shapes. It is then natural to try to apply tools from both equivariant cohomology and intersection theory to concrete problems in the field.

During the postdoc, we are also in the process of revising three papers submitted during the PI's time as a graduate student that connect algebraic geometry and enumerative geometry. These papers are "Equivariant degenerations of plane curve orbits" joint with M. Lee and A. Patel, "PGL2 equivariant strata of point configurations in P^1" joint with H. Spink, and "Divisors on the moduli space of curves from divisorial conditions on hypersurfaces".

The potential for application of algebraic geometry is underappreciated and the best way to contribute is to explore research in its intersection with other fields to make its methods better known. Through this postdoctoral fellowship, we have made a step in the right direction.


Last Modified: 02/01/2021
Modified by: Dennis Tseng
por.por_txt_cntn:
Algebraic geometry is the study of the geometries of shapes coming  from polynomial constraints. Because polynomial constraints are very  special, algebraic geometry is a specialized tool, but it is potentially  powerful when it can be applied. Therefore, we want to identify as many  connections between algebraic geometry and other fields as possible.  Even very theoretical fields have the potential to be applied to benefit  society in the long run, and we want to ensure techniques that might  only be currently understood by specialists to be eventually useful to  all. During this postdoctoral research fellowship, we specific pursue  connections two specific fields, which we will describe below.

Graphs  are defined by a collection of points and edges between them. Graphs face  the opposite problem as algebraic geometry above. Graphs are a very  general object, with little structure, so they already are applied in  many disciplines to solve problems. However, this generality comes at a  cost, namely the lack of structure reduces the its effectiveness in  dealing with any specific problem.

The main project pursued  during the postdoctoral fellowship deals with the connection between  certain graph invariants (more generally matroid invariants) and  algebraic geometry. The general idea that has been pursued in the  literature is to somehow encode the data of a graph in an algebraic  variety. Then, we have the best of both worlds, since we can apply the  specialized tools of algebraic geometry to a graph, which is a very  general object.

Our preprint, "Tautological bundles of matroids",  joint with A. Berget, C. Eur, and H. Spink, unifies many recent papers  in the literature that fit the theme above, bringing clarity to the  field.

The second direction pursued in the postdoctoral  fellowship is the application of algebraic geometric techniques to  equivariant cohomology. Cohomology is a tool in topology that can be  used to understand the intersection of certain shapes. Equivariant  cohomology allows one to exploit additional structure when there is  symmetry. Intersection theory is an important subfield of algebraic  geometry that also deals with understanding the intersection of shapes.  It is then natural to try to apply tools from both equivariant  cohomology and intersection theory to concrete problems in the field.

During  the postdoc, we are also in the process of revising three papers  submitted during the PI's time as a graduate student that connect  algebraic geometry and enumerative geometry. These papers are  "Equivariant degenerations of plane curve orbits" joint with M. Lee and  A. Patel, "PGL2 equivariant strata of point configurations in P^1" joint  with H. Spink, and "Divisors on the moduli space of curves from  divisorial conditions on hypersurfaces".

The potential for  application of algebraic geometry is underappreciated and the best way  to contribute is to explore research in its intersection with other  fields to make its methods better known. Through this postdoctoral  fellowship, we have made a step in the right direction.
